participants.title: This panel explores how political actors and the public make calculated decisions during disasters — not necessarily to optimize relief or resilience. These papers demonstrate how political actors often seek to manage perceptions, avoid blame, or gain political advantage during and after disaster while members of the public take cues from these political reactions.

participants.title: The papers in this panel deal with the broad issue of the role of institutions in environmental policy. section: CwC #8: Panel Discussion: Introducing the United States Emergency & Disaster Management Congress (USEDMC Thursday Conference Within A Conference
title: Discussants Churchill B2 - 2nd Tanya Buhler Corbin, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University Arthur Simental, US Emergency & Disaster Management Congress Disaster management and federal disaster policies are under scrutiny and debate in the U.S., with major institutions and agencies questioning and re-envisioning their structures, roles, and functions. These profound changes in the US emergency management s y stem are occurring at an accelerated pace, with input from the academic and practitioner community largely absent. Instead, disaster and emergency management policies are being developed and enacted based on partisan interests rather than current science and academic research. As disaster policy scholars have established, advocacy groups are necessary for successful policy change, which is lacking in th e disaster policy domain. An effort is now underway to bring together the disaster management community of scholars and practitioners through the United States Emergency & Disaster Management Congress (USEDMC), a nonpartisan, nonprofit professional association dedicated to influencing and shaping policy through legislative advocacy, education, and through the establishment of a unified national emergency & disaster management professional standard known as the “model emergency management law” and shared governance. Newly established, USEDMC represents emergency management professionals across the United State s from all U.S. states, territories, and tribes. In this roundtable discussion, we offer an overview of the organization, priorities, and progress of the organization and engage academic and practitioner stakeholders in a discussion of how to successfully ensure a robust, effective, and sustainable emergency and disaster management advocacy organization in the future.

section: Thriving as an International Graduate Student: Finding Your Identity in the PhD Thursday Teaching Political Science
title: Discussants Kobacoff - Raisa Castro-Avila, Georgia State University Rabia Sadiq, Georgia State University Deborah K Saki, Georgia State University This session is proposed as workshop. It centers the experiences of international graduate students and the often unspoken challenges they face in U.S. doctoral programs. While much professional development advice focuses on research, publishing, and career placement, international students often contend with additional barriers: cultural adjustment, visa restrictions, and limited access to networks. These issues directly shape well-being, productivity, and long-term success in academia and beyond. Rather than formal papers, this workshop will facilitate open discussion on strategies that cut across disciplines and communities inside and outside the department Managing well-being and productivity across borders and obligations Navigating funding, fellowships, and career opportunities as international students

participants.title: and grassroots strategies. The format will encourage audience participation, making space for graduate students in attendance to ask questions and exchange insights. The ultimate goal is to normalize conversations about international student well-being and direction, spotlight concrete practices that help students thrive, and foster a collaborative community that extends beyond SPSA.

section: The Politics of Culture, Communication and Finitude in Nietzsche, Jaspers and Arendt Thursday Political Theory
title: Chair Magazine - 3rd Constantine Vassiliou, University of Colorado, Colorado Springs

participants.title: Hannah Arendt and the Co-Verification of Reality through Action
participants.name: Natalie Moreira

participants.title: Nietzsche as Culture Physician: Nietzsche on “Philosophy in the Tragic Age of the Greeks” and his self- understanding as “the last disciple of the philosopher Dionysus”
participants.name: Dwight Allman

participants.title: Karl Jaspers and the Politics of Finitude
participants.name: Lee Ward

participants.title: Beyond the Ascetic Cocoon: An Examination of the Science of Politics in Nietzsche’s Genealogy of Morals
participants.name: Paul Kirkland

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Boleslaw Kabala

participants.title: Twentieth-century German political philosophy was profoundly influenced by Friedrich Nietzsche’s recovery of culture as a tool for diagnosing what he took to be the malaise of modern liberal democratic life. This panel explores Nietzsche’s cultural politics and the echoes of a cultural approach to the study of politics in Hannah Arendt’s theory of communication and action, as well as Karl Jaspers’ account of a politics based on finitude. Dwight Allman reconsiders the impact of Nietzsche’s early work The Birth of Tragedy by examining his early notes and unpublished writings (the Nachlass) and finds the roots of Nietzsche’s adoption of ancient Greek tragic culture, which would prove pivotal in his embrace of the persona “the last disciple of the philosopher Dionysius” in his later works Beyond Good and Evil and Twilight of the Idols. Paul Kirkland explores Nietzsche's argument about the cultural effects of the ascetic ideal which he associates with the modern scientific project. Kirkland argues that in Genealogy of Morals Nietzsche sought to fashion a new appearance for philosophy that does not require the mask of asceticism. Natalie Moreira engages the question of the philosophic meaning of culture by highlighting Arendt’s efforts to frame a political epistemology that can ground the multiple perspectives required to situate oneself in the realm of human affairs. For Moreira, one of Arendt’s signal achievements was to articulate a theory of communication that contributes to the improvised actions reflected in the individual’s right to organize a creative participatory political community. Lee Ward turns to Arendt’s mentor Karl Jaspers. Ward argues that this doyen of abstract existentialist philosophers actually had a very moderate political teaching grounded on his concept of “boundary situations” [Grenzsituationen]. For Jaspers the individual human being can only become an authentic self through a series of “leaps” from self to Existenz framed by the limits placed on action by material, social and political conditions rooted in historical reality. The paper concludes that Jaspers’ politics of finitude offers a compelling response to the integralist political and theological ambitions of many contemporary “post-liberal” thinkers such as Patrick Deneen and Adrian Vermeule. Taken altogether, the papers in this panel each highlight aspects of the relation of culture and politics that continue to resonate in contemporary life.

section: Author Meets Critics-The Politics of Individualism Thursday Public Opinion
title: Individualism is a quintessential American value, manifesting in emphases on hard work and economic independence. But there is another key aspect to individualism: moral autonomy, which must be understood in the context of an individual's relationship to authority. Autonomy has been a central focus for political theory but overlooked in the empirical measures most often used by political scientists The Politics of Individualism (2025, Oxford University Press) emphasizes the importance of moral autonomy by examining the relationship between autonomy, the self, and institutions. The book explores the conceptual dimensions of individualism, introduces a new empirical measure ("moral individualism"), and evaluates its relationship to civic life. People who score highly on the moral individualism scale are less likely to commit to public goods and to engage in collective efforts to alleviate common problems, even in the midst of a pandemic that threatened the physical health of millions around the world. In light of these findings, the book assesses the danger that moral individualism may pose to the maintenance of democratic institutions and the common goals and beliefs that help bind a nation together. In this panel, our aim is to explore the empirical advances made in The Politics of Individualism and their implications. Because a central goal of the panel is to bring together both political theorists and empirical political scientists, we anticipate the panel will include both types of scholars. We are still in the process of finalizing the list of critics, but our aim for the panel will be to provide a brief overview of the argument in the book, followed by constructive discussion from each of four critics. Given the content of the book, we view this panel as a unique opportunity to promote dialogue between political philosophers and empirical researchers as they explore the book and its findings. 2600 CwC #7: Wartime Politics Thursday Conference Within A Conference Chair Churchill B1 - 2nd Milan Svolik, Yale University

participants.name: David Whitney

participants.title: The first quarter of the 21st century has been marked by a steady decline of trust in institutions, extending beyond the government to universities, churches, and science. Increased polarization has accompanied this loss of trust, as an appreciable number of citizens now view their fellow citizens as enemies. This panel seeks to identify some of the causes of this decline, with an emphasis on various "isms." Potential solutions will also be examined.

section: Thucydides and Plato: Thinking Through the Cave of Empire Thursday Political Theory
title: Chair Magazine - 3rd Borden Flanagan, American University

participants.title: What’s So Good About the Good? Pericles and Socrates on the Politics of Eros
participants.name: Borden Flanagan

participants.title: A Metaphysical Thucydides? Reading the ‘History’ in Light of Plato’s Timaeus and Critias
participants.name: Bernard J Dobski

participants.title: Some Remarks on Plato’s Use of Thucydides
participants.name: Alex Priou

participants.title: Thucydidean Dialogue and Plato
participants.name: Charlotte Thomas

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Clifford Orwin

participants.title: Many commentators have written on the Peloponnesian war as it figures as the historical setting of Platonic dialogues, but relatively little attention has been paid to Plato’s relation to Thucydides the thinker or Thucydides the writer. The depth of Thucydides’ account of politics and “the human thing” and the artistry of his text are widely accepted, so the neglect is strange. The Platonic dialogues offer an account of Socrates, who brought philosophy down to the city, and Thucydides, Socrates’ contemporary, is arguably the greatest and certainly the most immediate of Plato’s predecessors. Once the question of their connection is raised signs of Thucydides’ influence on Plato emerge, as do more surprising indications: reading Plato in light of Thucydides allows one to read Thucydides in light of Plato. That is, alertness to Plato’s artistry and to his account of how philosophic questions emerge from political ones allows for a more philosophically rich understanding of the substance and procedure of Thucydides’ text. This panel brings together scholars of Thucydides and Plato to begin to give the connection between the two thinkers it’s due.

participants.name: Christopher M. Brown

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Georgina Chami

participants.title: This panel examines the evolving political, social, and economic landscapes of the Caribbean through interdisciplinary case studies that highlight both systemic challenges and community resilience. One paper explores how Indigenous Caribbean communities adapt to shifting societal pressures while preserving cultural identity, offering insight into grassroots resilience amid modernization. Another traces Saint Lucia’s democratic evolution, analyzing how small island states navigate global political currents while maintaining institutional stability. A third paper investigates the operational capacity of law enforcement agencies across CARICOM nations in confronting transnational cocaine trafficking, revealing disparities in institutional effectiveness and regional cooperation. The panel also addresses ecological vulnerability through an analysis of foreign overfishing’s impact on Caribbean livelihoods, demonstrating how external exploitation threatens both economic survival and environmental sustainability. Finally, the persistent crisis of human trafficking is examined as a product of poverty, weak governance, and organized crime, underscoring the need for coordinated policy responses. Together, these papers illuminate the complex interplay between external pressures and internal governance, revealing how Caribbean societies confront entrenched vulnerabilities while striving for democratic resilience, social equity, and sustainable development.

Join us for a dynamic discussion about the promise, pitfalls, and real-world experiences across these domains. How have AI tools enhanced learning experiences, streamlined research processes, and fostered innovation in political science? Attendees can expect an engaging exchange of ideas on navigating the evolving landscape of technology in academia - with an emphasis on practical tips and concrete steps to consider in your own work.

section: The Roads to Congress, an assessment of the 2024 elections and their political and electoral implications for 2026 Friday Campaigns and Elections
title: Chair Bridge - Riverside Walter Wilson, University of Texas at San Antonio Discussants Douglas Brattebo, University of Texas Rio Grande Valley Barsky Christina, University of Vermont Jeffrey Kraus, Wagner College Joe Caiazzo, The JNC Group/Endicott College Led by authors contributing to the “Roads to Congress 2024” book manuscript, this roundtable will evaluate factors that shaped outcomes in the 2024 congressional elections, discuss their implications, and look ahead to the 2026 midterms and the next edition of the Roads to Congress. Key topics for discussion may include: · Strengthening the Roads to Congress series as a scholarly resource and pedagogical tool · Reasons for and implications of evolving party demographic support · Patterns of realignment in the electorate and the political implications of these trends · Innovations in campaign strategies by candidates, parties, and groups · Reasons for and implications of evolving issue cleavages between partisan candidates · Developments in and implications of recent changes in election laws, including mid-decade redistricting The goals of the roundtable are to promote innovative new research appearing in the ongoing “Roads to Congress” book series, highlight and build synergy between emerging scholarly interpretations of contemporary electoral politics, provide opportunities for scholars to network and catalyze future collaborative research on campaigns and elections, and strengthen the collaboration and coherence of scholarly contributions to the next edition of the book.

title: Chair Chequers - 2nd Nathan Edenhofer, University of California Santa Cruz

participants.title: Varieties of Mining Deals in the Lithium Triangle
participants.name: Lucas I Gonzalez

participants.title: Gold, Labor, and Crime: ASMG Workers' Organizations and Criminality in Peru
participants.name: Omayra Peña Jimenez

participants.title: Movement Leverage and Mining Capital Paralysis in Guatemala
participants.name: Nathan Edenhofer

participants.title: Obstacles to Attaining a Social License to Operate: An Analysis of Corporate-Community Relations in the Chilean Atacama Desert
participants.name: Juliette Maasland

participants.title: Green Development at the Crossroads: Lithium and the Politics of Industrial Policy in the Americas
participants.name: Tamara Ortega-Uribe

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Moises Arce

participants.title: This panel brings new research on pressing questions surrounding the politics of resource extraction in the Americas. Latin America is experiencing a renewed mining rush, driven by the demand for “green energy transition” minerals like lithium, copper, and nickel, while the price of gold has reached historic highs amid geopolitical and geo-economic tensions and uncertainty. However, unlike at the start of the commodity supercycle from 2002-2013, companies seeking to extract these minerals now encounter communities shaped by two decades of conflicts both against mining and over the terms of mining, while debates over the benefits versus harms of extractivism have intensified. At the same time, countries are increasingly engaging in the illicit and unregulated extraction of both old and new commodities, such as gold and copper. With the context more relevant than ever, the papers in the panel place an emphasis on power and the strategic action that communities, corporations, labor organizations, and state entities take as determining the outcomes of extractive politics. These dynamics through how the variation in labor organizing of artisanal gold miners across territories allows or prevents the influence of criminal organizations in Peru (Peña Jimenez); how territorial conflicts and dynamics lead to negotiated, unnegotiated, or aborted lithium projects in the Atacama’s Lithium Triangle of Argentina, Chile, and Bolivia (González and Snyder); how the dynamics of territorial struggles led to near total national paralysis of mining in Guatemala (Edenhofer); how the contradictions of company-community relations create or inhibit mobilization in Chile’s lithium sector (Maasland); and how the attempts to create post- neoliberal green industrial policy in the lithium sector in Chile and California expose the tensions between state-led industrial policy, local opposition, neocolonial structures and geopolitics of critical minerals (Ortega).

section: “The Victory Paradox: The Challenge of Converting Success on the Battlefield into Strategic Victory in War” Friday International Conflict and Security
title: Chair Commerce - 3rd Marc Genest, US Naval War College

participants.title: “The Victory Paradox: The Challenge of Converting Success on the Battlefield into Strategic Victory in the Vietnam War”
participants.name: Cavender Sutton

participants.title: “The Illusion of Decision: Japan’s Inability Defeat Nationalist China”
participants.name: Andrew Wilson

participants.title: “Israel’s War Against Hamas: The Challenge of Translating Escalation Dominance on the Battlefield to a better state of Peace.”
participants.name: Marc Genest

participants.title: China’s Gray Zone activity in the Western Pacific: Part of a Flawed Strategy
participants.name: Craig Whiteside

participants.title: Victory as a Theoretical Paradox: The Difficulties of Understanding and Teaching Strategic Victory in Great Power Competition"
participants.name: Vanya Eftimova Bellinger

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Cavender Sutton

participants.title: Using case studies drawn from numerous historical and contemporary wars, this panel examines the challenges of converting success on the battlefield into strategic victory. While military success is generally considered essential in winning a conflict, many factors make it challenging to achieve a political outcome that justifies the blood and treasure expended by military operations. Panelists will draw from the conflicts in Asia, Southeast Asia, the Middle East and other regions to assess the conditions under which battlefield dominance is a decisive factor in achieving political objectives and when military success fails to produce the desired aims of the belligerents. The following questions will be addressed. Has the nature of modern warfare made military dominance more problematic? How did the political and social context within which the conflict was waged impact its outcome? Where the political aims of the belligerents clearly defined and realistic? Did the adversaries adequately reassess and adapt to changes on the battlefield? Did international institutions and global public opinion play a meaningful role in bring the war to an end?

participants.title: Gender Reform and Legal Transformation in Revolutionary Cuba
participants.name: Christopher M. Brown

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Georgina Chami

participants.title: This panel explores the multifaceted legacies of revolutionary Cuba through historical, legal, and transnational lenses. Anchored in the Cold War moment, one paper revisits the Bay of Pigs invasion to interrogate John F. Kennedy’s strategic calculus and its implications for U.S.–Cuban relations. Another examines the entanglement of public and private corruption in Cuba, revealing how informal networks and state structures co-evolved under communism. A third contribution traces the enduring influence of the Cuban diaspora on contemporary U.S. foreign policy, highlighting how exile communities have shaped legislative agendas and diplomatic postures. Finally, a legal-historical analysis of gender reforms in revolutionary Cuba assesses both the progressive aspirations and persistent limitations of state-led transformation. Together, these papers present a nuanced portrait of Cuba, not as a static revolutionary symbol, but as a dynamic site of contestation, where ideology, governance, and identity intersect across borders and over decades. By bridging domestic and international perspectives, the panel invites critical reflection on Cuba’s evolving role in global politics and the complex interplay between reform, resistance, and remembrance.

participants.title: Academic Utilization and Issue Novelty
participants.name: Connor William Dye
participants.affiliation: University of Texas at San Antonio

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Leigh Hersey

participants.title: Higher education organizations (HEOs) are being called to become more engaged with their communities. Kerr (2001), in some of the most well-known literature in this area, highlights the role of universities within society arguing that place and space are central to understanding how HEOs integrate themselves within their societies and communities. From the initial land grant universities to the more recent Carnegie Community Engagement Elective Classification, different models of engagement and impact have been put forth. This panel will explore these models and practices of engagement. The first paper examines the missions of land grant universities, urban-serving universities, extension programs, and engaged scholarship, identifying overlaps and gaps. The next paper focuses on rural community research conducted in West Texas (the Panhandle and South Plains regions), including the presence of third spaces and the strengths and challenges of these communities. The third paper presents how a regional university has implemented a statewide training program for public defenders. The final paper demonstrates how partnering public libraries can fill the engagement gaps, particularly in rural communities. Attendees will be able to take this knowledge back to their own universities and develop and enhance their own projects to engage with their communities.

Scherlen, Appalachian State University Ellen Key, Appalachian State University Andrea Eckelman, University of Montevallo Rebecca Reid, University of Texas at El Paso Kristyn Karl, Stevens Institute Maureen Stobb, Georgia Southern University Alixandra Yanus, High Point University Maya Fields, University of Central Florida Meghan Iverson, university of chicago Join SPSA Women for a networking session across the discipline -- all SPSA conference attendees are welcome! This interactive opportunity is designed to encourage meaningful connections despite a short amount of time. Attendees will engage in a series of brief, small group conversations - each person will participate in a subfield research conversation designed to foster collaboration before self-selecting two additional topics. This format encourages efficient networking while also helping scholars connect across the field. participants.title: Socrates’ Dream and the Possibility of Platonic Political Philosophy in the Crito
participants.name: Matthew Oberrieder

participants.title: According to the classical tradition, and articulated most famously by Aristotle, human beings are by nature both rational and political animals. As Aristotle goes on to say, politics is prior by nature to the human being; humanity as such, that is, is impossible without the rational faculty developed by communal living. Speech (logos) comes to sight as logically prior but ontologically posterior to political life: politics is the subject of speech by political philosophers, who debate about justice and the advantageous, but politics also presupposes the ability to speak and reason about these same subjects. This panel explores speech as both the sine qua non of the practice of politics, and also the means by which theorists treat the subject of political life.

section: Author Meets Critics: Saladin Ambar's Murder on the Mississippi: The Shocking Crimes That Shaped Abraham Lincoln Friday Presidential and Executive Politics
title: Chair Steering - Riverside Justin Vaughn, Coastal Carolina University Discussants Saladin Ambar, Rutgers University Jamie Carson, University of Georgia Melvin Laracey, University of Texas San Antonio Richard M. Yon, United States Military Academy This panel will feature a robust discussion of Saladin Ambar's recent book, Murder on the Mississippi: The Shocking Crimes that Shaped Abraham Lincoln (Diversion). Amid the string of murders on the American frontier, Lincoln faced the loss of his first love—and a descent into suicidal despair. Yet from this darkness, he emerged with a renewed purpose, one that would define his leadership in the fight for democracy, human freedom, and the rule of law. In Murder on the Mississippi, Ambar unearths the horrors that shaped a young Abraham Lincoln’s worldview, pushing him to find his political voice in one of the earliest and most pivotal speeches of his career. Confronted by lawlessness, racial terror, and his own inner demons, Lincoln’s battle was political and deeply personal. From the flames of mob violence rose a young Lincoln, forged in fire and soon to contend with a nation at war with itself. 3700 Access to Justice: Representation in the Courts Friday Judicial Politics

section: Reforming Oversight in an Era of Executive Supremacy Saturday Presidential and Executive Politics
title: Chair Churchill B2 - 2nd Jesse Crosson, Purdue University

participants.title: Building Congressional Processing to Respond to Loper-Bright
participants.name: Soren Dayton

participants.title: Civil Service Reform: Recent Theoretical and Empirical Work
participants.name: Daniel Gibbs

participants.title: Making Oversight Great Again: Reforming Congressional Investigations in the Age of Trump
participants.name: Claire Leavitt

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Henry B. Sirgo

participants.title: This panel examines the institutional challenges and opportunities facing executive-congressional relations in an era of rapid legal and political changes. One paper explores how the demise of the Chevron doctrine creates a need for Congress to develop procedural mechanisms that activate legislative decision- making based on expert agency findings. Another critically surveys emerging literature on civil service reform, focusing on the sometimes counterintuitive implications of proposals like Schedule F for bureaucratic accountability and politicization. The final paper analyzes how the Trump administration exposed the fragility of congressional oversight, and offers historical and practical reforms to strengthen investigative capacity in the face of executive resistance. Together, these papers offer a roadmap for rebalance congressional and executive power, focusing on expertise, procedural muscle, and institutional resilience in the post-Chevron era.

section: Author Meets Critics Roundtable: "Religious Liberty: A Conservative Primer" by John Wilsey Saturday Religion and Politics
title: Discussants Cambridge - 2nd Glenn A Moots, Northwood University Michael Federici, Middle Tennessee State University James Patterson, University of Tennessee Knoxville Michael Lucchese, Liberty Fund John Wilsey, Southern Baptist Theological Seminary This “Author Meets Critics” roundtable will discuss John Wilsey's book “Religious Liberty: A Conservative Primer" (Eerdmans). Wilsey advances what he calls "aspirational conservatism" to revive conservatism in an age of postliberalism, populism, and MAGA. Of particular interest to Wilsey is the phenomena of religious postliberalism (the revival of integralism or magisterial Protestantism) and its consequences for liberalism. The panel will discuss the survival of traditional conservatism in an age of populism and MAGA and the religious dimensions of liberalism and postliberalism. Roundtable

participants.title: State University), Michael Lucchese (Hudson Institute/Hillsdale/Liberty Fund), Glenn Moots (Northwood University)

participants.title: With confidence in American institutions at historic lows and policymaking bodies seemingly incapable of addressing an ever-growing list of societal challenges, the idea of institutional reform has grown in popularity across the U.S. This panel will consider potential statutory reforms to the federal judiciary. This includes analysis of the proper scope of judicial authority (as established by Congress under Article III of the Constitution), the politics of authorization of judicial seats (which has key implications for the efficient administration of justice and judicial capacity), and the way Supreme Court justices are selected.

section: Disrupting Political Science: Black Women Reimagining the Discipline Saturday Race and Ethnicity
title: Chairs Prince of Wales - Sharon Austin, University of Florida Angela Lewis-Maddox, University of Alabama, Birmingham Discussants Mea Boykins, University of the West Indies Robin L Turner, Butler University Nikol Alexander Floyd, Rutgers University Lakeytta Bonnette-Bailey, Howard University Jamil Scott, Georgetown University A panel of Black female political science professors and students will discuss their experiences as researchers and educators in the discipline of political science. They will discuss their experiences with intersectional discrimination on the basis of their race, gender, and other identities. They will also provide advice to other scholars about the best ways to navigate their experiences when dealing with students, colleagues, and the tenure and promotion process. The participants in their panel will discuss their chapters in the Disrupting Political Science: Black Women Reimagining the Discipline book, edited by Dr. Angela Lewis-Maddox of the University of Alabama, Birmingham. 4200 Perspectives on Law and Courts Saturday Judicial Politics

section: CwC #9: Author-Meets-Critics Saturday Conference Within A Conference
title: Participant Churchill B1 - 2nd Politicizing Business: How Firms Are Made to Serve the Party-State in China Ning Leng, Georgetown University Discussants Hiroki Takeuchi, Southern Methodist University (SMU) Yao-Yuan Yeh, University of St. Thomas Zhu Zhang, Fairfield University An author-meets-critic roundtable discussing "Politicizing Business: How Firms Are Made to Serve the Party-State in China" by Ning Leng. 4400 CwC #13: Faculty Panel: Ancients vs. Moderns Saturday Conference Within A Conference Chair Churchill B2 - 2nd Ronna Burger, Tulane University

participants.title: Herodotus, Aeschylus, and Sophocles on the Ancient Political Project
participants.name: Frank Pagano

participants.title: Aristotle ’ s Political Dialogue
participants.name: Rachel Mackey

participants.title: Montesquieu ’ s Persian Letters: Enlightenment and Despotism
participants.name: Janet Dougherty

participants.title: Machiavelli ’ s Knives
participants.name: Michael Hoffapuir

participants.title: The capstone panel of our CWC puts in tension ancient and modern political philosophy. Dr. Frank Pagano (St. John ’ s College, Annapolis) considers antiquity as a project articulated by Herdotus, Sophocles, and Aeschylus. Dr. Rachel Mackey (Hudson Institute) articulates Aristotle ’ s understanding of the fundamental conditions for political life and asks whether the classical notion of politics still exists, or indeed can exist, in the modern age. Dr. J. Michael Hoffpauir (University of Austin) explores in Machiavelli ’ s mentions of “ knives ” his modern conceptions of fortune, god, cruelty, and the divine. Janet Dougherty (St. John ’ s College, Annapolis) concludes with a book that bridges ancient and modern thought, Montesquieu ’ s Persian Letters . She inquire s about the relationship between the modern scientific method and ancient philosophy ’ s quest for self - knowledge, as well as between despotism and enlightened government. Taken together, these presentations aim to present ancient and modern conceptions of politics and philosophy and ask what students of politics can learn by putting them in dialogue with one another. Panel members will respond to one another.

participants.name: Craig Koch

participants.title: The Implications of Socratic Philosophy for a Secular Society: Justice and the Holy in Plato's Euthyphro
participants.name: Dylan Jackson

participants.title: Xenophon ’ s Playful Posse: Lightheartedness in Portrayals of Socrates
participants.name: Emma Bernstein MacFarlane

participants.title: Aristotle on Thymos and Moral Education
participants.name: Maria Goyette

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Rachel Mackey

participants.title: This graduate student panel aims to understand philosophy as a way of life: particularly, the proper ordering of soul and community that the ancients thought was a necessary precondition for philosophy. Craig Koch (Tulane University) investigates “ the spirited relationship to truth without which the philosophers ’ erotic pursuit of truth would not be possible. ” Dylan Jackson (St. John ’ s College, Annapolis) reads the Euthyphro for lessons relevant to a modern secular nation. Emma Bernstien MacFarlane asks whether “ lightheartedness [is] something Xenophon understands to be a necessary part of the good life, ” and why Socrates countenances the presence of lighthearted men in his company. Maria Goyette (Baylor University, fellow at Cleveland State University) takes up how Aristotle ’ s moral education aims to refine the quality of spiritedness, so important to politics and a well - ordered soul. These presentations will suggest how Socrates, Plato, Xenophon, and Aristotle shape the education of the philosopher while articulating the shocking claim that philosophy is essential for politics.

section: Seeking Research Funding from Foundations: Grant and Fellowship Opportunities for Political Scientists Saturday Program Chair's Panels
title: Chair James A Wilson, Russell Sage Foundation Participant Seeking Research Funding from Foundations: Grant and Fellowship Opportunities for Political Scientists James A Wilson, Russell Sage Foundation Discussants Andra Gillespie, Emory University Lee Walker, National Science Foundation Jan Leighley, National Science Foundation Seeking research funding is an increasingly competitive process and preparing a successful application can be a challenging and time-consuming exercise. This session will provide a practical overview of applying for research support in political science from two high-profile funders of social, political and policy research. The panel includes (1) program staff from from the National Science Foundation and the Russell Sage Foundation, and (2) academic scholars who have applied for and received funding as well as served as reviewers for the process. Funder panelists will discuss their funding priorities, the grant writing and review process and the basics of what makes a good grant proposal, processes for developing ideas for funding and budgeting, and resources that specify what to include in research proposals. With extensive funding experience and evaluating proposals as part of the grant-making process, funder panelists will discuss how to develop and write a sound grant application from the perspective of a funding organization. Scholar panelists will discuss and provide insights about the application and review process from the grant-seeking side. A key focus will be on tips for good grant-writing – the specifics of what often makes for a good grant proposal and the mistakes that grant-seekers should avoid in drafting an application.

section: Reconsidering Plato’s Caves: The Liberating Sting of Cultural Diversity Saturday Political Theory
title: Chair Magazine - 3rd Ann Ward, Baylor University Discussants Rebecca LeMoine, Florida Atlantic University Robert Ballingall, University of Maine Alex Orwin, Louisiana State University Mary Townsend, St. john's University Given the rise of illiberalism, nativism, and authoritarianism in our politics today, bringing with it the attack on the “woke” concepts of diversity, equity and inclusion and promises of the detention and mass deportations of immigrants, it is all the more imperative that we reflect on the impact of Plato’s Caves: The Liberating Sting of Cultural Diversity (Oxford University Press, 2020) by Rebecca LeMoine. In Plato’s Caves, LeMoine argues, contrary to the popular and scholarly narrative, that Plato was a friend of cultural diversity. Through a careful reading of four Platonic dialogues, the Republic, Menexenus, Laws, and Phaedrus, LeMoine shows that far from exhibiting hostility toward foreigners, they reveal that foreigners paly a role similar to that of Socrates: the role of gadfly. Like encounters with Socrates, interactions with foreigners can expose contradictions in the authoritative opinions that undergird one’s political community and thus encourage a more self-reflective citizenship. They can do this, according to LeMoine, because every citizen lives in a polity that shares the basic features of the cave, Plato’s famous allegory in the Republic. This means that when we interact with someone raised in a different “cave,” we are faced with the possibility of another way of life and hence with the occasion to reflect on our own conception of truth, beauty, and goodness. Foreigners, in other words, help us to see our cave as a cave, hence showing us that we live in a world of cave-like polities from which we can nonetheless be freed. LeMoine also argues that studying Plato’s views on foreigner’s gives deeper insight into his attitudes toward democracy, and concludes with reflections on how Plato’s portrayal of foreigners as gadflies can speak to our contemporary debate on cultural diversity. According to LeMoine, Plato shows how the “liberating sting” of cross-cultural engagement, although initially painful, can help citizens cultivate a Socratic knowledge of ignorance and hence the intellectual humility that is essential to the preservation of democracy. Plato, LeMoine argues, shows that democracy’s downfall into tyranny happens when citizens develop intellectual hubris that rejects education and the exposure to cultural diversity that it brings.

participants.title: This panel examines how organizations, money, and geography shape American politics. Hall and Sun document the rise of corporate policy teams, showing that firms increasingly invest more in internal political expertise than in traditional lobbying. Berry and Fowler trace the shifting geography of economic productivity and partisan alignment, highlighting how the new political economy of place reshapes distributive politics. Fouirnaies shows how interest group endorsements tilt primary elections, underscoring how organized groups channel support to favored candidates. Finally, Buisseret presents a formal model of elections in which the incentives of campaigns to raise money from small donors leads to polarized platforms. Together, these papers reveal the diverse ways in which money, expertise, geography, and group support shape contemporary American politics, offering new perspectives on the anatomy of influence beyond the ballot box.

section: CwC #12: Validation and LLMs in Political Science Saturday Conference Within A Conference
title: Discussants Churchill C1 - 2nd Ethan C Busby, Brigham Young University Lisa Argyle, Purdue University Joshua Gubler, Brigham Young University This roundtable discussion follows up on a related working group at the 2025 APSA meeting in Vancouver, CA. It is intended as a step towards developing a set of validation practices and standards for working with generative AI tools in political science. Work using generative AI tools in political science has dramatically increased, but researchers still lack a set of best practices to validate and justify the use of generative AI tools in their many applications. This leaves scholars, reviewers, funders, and the discipline at large unsure how to evaluate the quality of research using generative AI in political science. We intend for the scope of this conversation to include best practices and evaluation standards related, but not limited, to: extent and disclosure of AI use in the research process, transparency and replicability, metrics and benchmarks for task - specific performance, and model selection

participants.name: Ingrid Neves Magalhaes

participants.title: Discussant
participants.name: Hannah Baron

participants.title: How do citizens and political actors navigate violence, and how do their strategies shape democracy and state authority? This panel brings together research on Colombia, Mexico, and Brazil to examine the politics between victims, movements, and politicians in contexts of conflict and insecurity. In Colombia, unarmed movements mobilize for land redistribution even amid armed conflict to achieve redistributive reform through peace processes. In some parts of Mexico, victims and local communities leverage violence through extralegal practice to engage with or pressure state institutions, while in others, they organize collectively but deliberately avoid state institutions. In Brazil, politicians strategically deploy repression-based appeals that influence public support for police violence and shape attitudes toward police reforms. Taken together, these studies show how citizens and elites negotiate the terms of violence and order, with consequences for redistribution, state accountability, and democratic governance in Latin America.
